intro: Gmelina salomonensis f. glabrescens, commonly known as the smooth-leaved gum tree, is a variant of the Gmelina salomonensis species native to parts of Southeast Asia. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters, characterized by its smooth, grey bark and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, fragrant flowers that are usually white or pale yellow, followed by elongated, woody fruits containing several seeds. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in moist, well-drained soils near riverbanks or in lowland forests. This species is valued for its timber and is also used in traditional medicine in some regions.
